awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: FishLife: genealogy and traits of living and fossil vertebrates that never left the water
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop and apply a unified framework for studying the evolution of all fishes, including lampreys, sharks, and the coral reef, deep sea and freshwater fishes. This work will illuminate the genealogical relationships (phylogeny), evolutionary timing, and mechanisms for the origin and maintenance of the world's diversity of fishes, including the most important food and aquarium fishes. The project will contribute to community-driven scientific efforts, to student training, to web content and application development, and to public outreach. All fish specimens, specimen and DNA data, and analytical results obtained will be made publicly available through a dynamic and open structure that complies with established standards to facilitate wide accessibility to the broader scientific and non-scientific communities. High school, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral student training are central activities for this project. Social media outreach and training will provide diverse professional development opportunities as well. A fish species identification application for smartphones based on image data (FishSnap) will be developed and made freely available to the public to allow accurate identification of selected groups of fishes. Outcomes of this project will form part of a new public exhibit at the National Museum of Natural History to highlight the value of specimen collections at natural history museums.

This integrative project will combine genomic, paleontological, anatomical, functional, ecological, and comparative approaches. The research team blends strengths in collections-based research on fishes, molecular and morphological phylogenetics, bioinformatics, and comparative analyses, allowing them to synthesize big data sets to resolve the phylogeny of all described fish species and conduct evolutionary analysis of key traits. Time-calibrated trees will be used to reveal diversification patterns of the major groups. Image analysis, morphometrics, and phenomic data will enable the discovery of evolutionary patterns in size, shape, and biomechanical function across thousands of species.

por.por_cntn:
The central theme of this grant was to build the Tree of Life for fishes and use the branching pattern of fish relationships to explore patterns of evolution and function. A collaboration across 4 institutions and over 5 years (extended to 6 years due to the pandemic), our Chicago part of the collaboration was to build the tree of life (phylogeny) for coral reef fish families and assemble large data sets on traits such as body size, ecology, and function to empower evolutionary studies. This grant enabled us to make major progress on multiple lines of inquiry, including phylogenetic relationships at multiple levels of resolution among reef fishes, assembly and analysis of large data layers of functional and ecological data for fishes, including morphometrics and mechanical properties of jaws and fins, and broad evolutionary patterns of biogeography, fish shape, and biomechanical function. The project also supported the research projects and career advancement of many people.

Graduate students Charlene McCord (now faculty at CSUDH), Andrew George (Postdoc at Field Museum) and Chloe Nash (current PhD student) were partially supported by this grant and have contributed to phylogenetics research, data layer assembly and evolutionary analyses. Dr. McCord performed detailed analysis of phylogenetics and biomechanics in the triggerfishes and filefishes, revealing the evolutionary history of multiple subdivisions of the jaw muscles and the unusual cranial morphology and function. Dr. George assembled fin shape and locomotor data layers for balistoid fishes and performed phylomorphospace analyses, showing extensive convergence in fin shapes, and exploring novel patterns of asymmetry in fin design. Chloe Nash is exploring reef fish phylogenetics on goatfishes, damselfishes, and labrid fishes, with extensive biogeographic and trait data layer assembly. Her recent work discovered asymmetry in transitions among ecotypes in damselfishes, that are significantly associated with patterns of diversification. In addition, Dr. Brett Aiello (now postdoc at Georgia Tech) worked on a large evolutionary integration of fin shapes and fin mechanics in the context of a new phylogeny of wrasses, revealing that high aspect ratio fins have evolved at least 32 times and show strong associations with fin stiffness and locomotor behavior.

This grant also made significant advances in phylogenomics, with the addition of Dr. Lily Hughes (Postdoctoral Researcher) in January 2020. Her work has generated exon-capture phylogenomic data for several reef fish groups, including 220 species of Labridae and 72 species of Mullidae, with other large, species-rich families also being sequenced and analyzed. Her scientific contributions will result in a series of papers on phylogenomics and total-evidence genomic-Sanger data phylogenetic analyses, as well as evolutionary analyses of several trait layers being assembled in ecology and biomechanics. Her research forms the foundation for a new project and future proposal on functional genomics, examining how anatomical and functional diversity is related to genomic diversity. Dr. Hughes scientific contributions are complemented by her skills at student mentorship and collaboration, which have been especially welcome during the difficult pandemic year.

Broader outcomes and products.  Six undergraduate students from UChicago worked on this award including Linnea Lungstrom, Kelly Kang, Theresa Tatum-Naecker, Jacob Feingold, Isaac Krone, and Hannah Weller. Lungstrom, Krone, Tatum-Naecker, and Weller are now graduate students in prominent programs. Tatum-Naecker and Weller both authored publications related to this project, each of the others has projects in draft and all but 1 have presented at the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology. The PI and most of the personnel above have performed public outreach, including volunteering at the Field Museum in public events, and participating in the Science Olympiad for students in local public schools. The grant funded several fish-themed synthesis meetings in collaboration with the FuturePhy program, a workshop for students in fish phylogenetics at the JMIH meetings, and development of content on social media about fishes. All fish specimens and tissues have been preserved and deposited in the Field Museum collections. Primary data is deposited in DataDryad, and in publication supplements, with additional availability on ResearchGate. Code packages in R are available on CRAN, and ObjC code and app development code is deposited on the mwestneat github repository.


Last Modified: 02/22/2022
Modified by: Mark Westneat

Image
  • The pattern of evolution in body size in 345 damselfishes, illustrated on their Tree of Life. Asymmetry between size categories was found to be a significant factor in damselfish diversification.
    Mark W. Westneat
    Public Domain
    Mark Westneat
    Size Evolution in Damselfishes
